textPlain: I’ve started using Jujutsu recently and was surprised at how low friction it was to switch. If you’re like the author and keep hearing about it without giving it a shot, I suggest you just sit down and try it – it’s a lot less effort than you might expect.
I think this is the first blog on JJ that has made me want to use it. The flow seems like it could be quite a bit better than git
Jujutsu is so good. I'm using a megamerge workflow and absolutely loving it!
How are these patch sets reviewed? Is there some mechanism for integrating with review systems like GitHub?

I started using jujutsu after the last round of blog posts here, and have found it super super useful to my mental model of git and vcs.Stealing Fintan's `jj tug` alias from this post is something I have already found useful. Highly recommend if anyone is on the edge of trying to just give it a shot!
Just waiting for Jujutsu to support submodules and I can replace git completely.
I tried Jujutsu on a simple repo and it ended up a mess I couldn't fix. Never had that with git. Might be my lack of knowledge but it shouldn't allow this.
Follow along with Fintan as he details how he put his Git workflow into submission with Jujutsu and Radicle

Yup. Still 0 incentive to try jj. I’m still very much convinced most of the problems solved by jj either do not exist or are already solved by recent features of git.It’s good alternatives of popular tools exist but git would not be my first bet as a tool that needs fixing…

From git's perspective, jj bookmarks are just regular git branches, so you can just do `jj git push` and open a PR as usual.However, unlike git, jj bookmarks are pinned to change IDs instead of immutable commit SHA-1s. This means that stacked PRs just work: Change something in the pr-1 bookmark, and all dependent bookmarks (pr-2, pr-3, ...) are automatically updated. A `jj git push --tracked` later and everything is pushed.
I really hope they don't add submodule support. There's an opportunity to do something that works properly!
jj undo, and jj op log && jj op restore can get you out of any trouble.
Why say yup to disagree with the premise of the article?
“You miss 100% of the shots you didn’t take” - Michael Scott.
I mean, undo alone is a killer JJ feature. Sure, you can always somehow undo any git operation if you dig deep enough, but the ease of use on the JJ side without question.
